reviewText:
In an era where the video gaming industry has done away with art direction, atmosphere, brilliant writing, fun gameplay, unique mechanics and design, it's games like this that you appreciate a ♥♥♥♥ ton more now than you did back in the day. Soul Reaver is a shining example of how a game should be made today and contrary to being told that 'everything has been done already', this pisses in the face of that theory with the level of creativity and love put into it, which also happens to be a thing of the past.

In Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver you play the role of Raziel, formerly the vampiric Lieutenant of the vampire lord Kain, who stripped Raziel of his wings out of jealousy and cast him into The Lake of The Dead, Raziel is then resurrected as a wraith by The Elder God to become his Soul Reaver and gather souls and the strength to eventually gain enough power to kill Kain.

The level design is of Metroidvania-esque influence , giving you a massive open ended layout where you collect items which increase your health and energy, find powers (special attacks), uncover tons of cleverly hidden secrets and gain special abilities from defeating each boss that allow you to progress to places previously inaccessible on your quest to become the ultimate badass.

At it's core it boils down to combat, basic puzzle solving, exploration and platforming, but is set completely apart from any game of the kind with it's incredible (to say the least) plot, writing & lore, Godlike pacing that mixes all of said core elements together amazingly well so that none of them ever feel monotonous and stale, a genuinely evil art direction & theme, thick atmosphere, great level design, badass ♥♥♥♥in combat in which you have to 'fatality' enemies in varied manners such as impaling them with spears, throwing them into sunlight, spikes on the wall, pits of fire, pools of water which dissolves the ♥♥♥♥ers and many other badass ways after weakening them in combat which is then followed by devouring their souls which restores your life.

On a technical level, the visuals may appear dated to most at the first few glances but you get over that the instant you see how brilliant, unique and badass the art direction is, which is of far more importance than having millions of polygons that make up a bland, uninspired and soulless piece of ♥♥♥♥. The sound design is fantastic with everything sounding how it should, brilliant OST that blends in extremely well with the situations at hand and the voiced dialogue is simply of another caliber.

I HIGHLY recommend you play this with a controller and you're going to need to use Xpadder to map it as a keyboard as this game has a lot of issues with analogue sticks, that being my only gripe.

This is an essential game that is near flawless in every aspect that defines gaming and is a sad fact that a damn PS1 game nukes the ♥♥♥♥ out of any game of it's kind today.

reviewText:
(Ignore my time on record as I've spent most of my playtime offline)

Easily one of my most favorite games of all time! I remember playing this on the original Playstation like it was only yesterday. In my mind this game set the bar very high for what video games were capable of. Wonderfully written script and rich dialogue, Extremely clever puzzles that make you consider all possibilities. A unique and large open world game that managed to pull off one of the first concepts of streaming data directly from the disk, cutting out loading screens from area to area. Crystal Dynamics had outdone themselves when making this game, and it's a shame that we don't get games like this more often.

By today's standards this game would be considered a little rough around the edges (remember, this is 1999 we're talking about), but if you can look past its dated graphics and very rare glitches you will find a well crafted story with unique characters, all of whom are well rounded and are even pursuing their own goals.

Following the noble vampire Raziel, now turned undead wraith, on his journey to seek revenge for the betrayal of his creator Kain, you will find that the world they inhabit is dark and desolate, but not without reason. As their destinies unravel, you soon realize that there is more at stake than just Raziel's personal vengeance.

The Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver is heavy on storytelling and puzzle solving, but the combat isn't the best (in fact the combat is terrible). Many of the puzzles are far from obvious. Some are on such a large scale that you may have to visit several areas just to solve one and move on, but they are definitely rewarding as the further you go the more you learn of kain's actions, Raziel's resolve, and this dark, slowly dying world and how it came to be the way it is.

I have tried this on several computers and can easily say it runs quite well on modern machines. It runs on essentially any resolution, although I'd recommend playing at 4:3 resolution as that is what this game was made for. Widescreen works, but the game stretches. If it doesn't run well on yours then there may be a complication or something affecting its performance.

There is a problem with the audio, however. Sometimes the audio suffers from problems and you may miss some dialogue and key ambiant effects without realizing it, but it's easy to figure out as you can identify it when the sound starts to get choppy or, say, when you jump and the grunting noises you normally hear are missing. It's an easy fix, simply quit and restart. Now I know some people might find this a daunting task, and all I can do is assure you that this game is well worth the time and patience.

When I saw this game on steam, I was a little apprehensive to play it at first, as I was afraid my nostalgia would cloud the fact that this may be a terrible game after all. But once I ran it, I fell in love with it all over again. It can stand on it's own merits, and comes from a time where people were more worried about clever storytelling and breaking new ground than trying to introduce exclusive features and new DLC packs to increase product longevity. It's a masterpiece from another era, and shows that video games can be more than the generic Action Adventure" label that is used to describe them.

I wholeheartedly recommend this game and any other in the Legacy of Kain series."

reviewText:
My hours for this game on Steam are slim...but the hours I put forward on my original playstation version are far greater.  I was gifted the Legacy of Kain collection for my birthday last year and I'm thankful for that because I enjoy having digital copies of old beloved games.

As a warning, I find this difficult to play with just a keyboard and mouse, although it is possible. I’m currently looking for another way around this, as my controller does not hook up well either.  That is my only complaint. Keep in mind, as well, that this game was released almost 20 years ago so it has clunky graphics and textures but this makes me love the game even more. Nostalgia.

Even with it’s old graphics, I find this game quite eerie and creepy, although it has no horror tag. The characters, the story, the vampires/creatures and the music, ambience has always given me chills.

I think what makes me recommend this game is the plot.  It’s hard not to love a game with deep and captivating storyline.  Kain raised Raziel (the protagonist, whom you play) and his brothers from death, turning them into undead vampires. Kain saw an unfortunate fate in store for him in the future, and had plunged Raziel into the Abyss to save himself.  The vampires depicted in this game are supposed to evolve over time, becoming stronger, while gaining new abilities. Unfortunately many vampires were left weak, with few valuable skills after Kain took over Nosgoth. The “Elder God” brought Raziel back to life but not in his original form nor his vampire form. Many centuries had passed and the God deemed Raziel as his  ‘soul reaver’, to hunt down Kain and seek revenge, to save what was left of Nosgoth, which Kain had left in ruins.

You are given an option to switch between the living world and the spirit realm.  Raziel doesn’t necessarily have or need a weapon either. You can pick weapons up when you find them but you can also use your claws and tactics such as tossing your enemies in an open flame, sunlight spots or into water.  There’s also some strategy involved - mostly block puzzles - and you can collect glyphs to gain new abilities.

TLDR; 7/10 overall... Rich storyline, confusing controls at first. Worth a try if you like classic oldies, or dark fantasy/gothic adventure games.

I don't believe words alone can describe how amazing and groundbreaking this game was... so here's a link to a picture of a man juggling cats: http://monkeypickles.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Cat-Juggling.jpg

I'll properly start by voicing a complaint that the original Blood Omen is still not on Steam or GOG... Well now that that's out of the way I can move on to the game. Soul Reaver was my- well most peoples introduction to the Legacy Of Kain series and holy hellblazes did it leave an impression on me. The realm shifting gameplay was truly innovative at the time and the voice work, particularly the infallible Simon Templeman is incredible. That man has a voice crafted by the gods. On top of that the plot is astounding and a lot of it is all down to luck. If I recall correctly this game was heavily rushed by the publishers forcing the team (featuring video game goddess Amy Hennig) to cut out the original final portion, this led to them making a sequel. It could've ended here. Oh and the port is flawless so far, you might need a program to map an Xbox controller but my Nyko Airflo worked with it off the bat.

The music by Kurt Harland of Information Society in a time when video game scores by famous industrial musicians were increasingly popular creates the perfect soundscape and more significantly the song Ozar Midrashim that features prominently throughout the game adds a lot to what is possibly the single greatest opening FMV of all time. In fact I highly recommend you just go on YouTube and look it up, if that doesn't convince you I can pretty much bet that no words I could write here would.

This game, along with Metal Gear Solid are, for me, the absolute pinnacle of the PS1 era. I can't recommend this entire series enough.

Edit: I last played this on Vista on my old PC so I don't know how it runs on Windows 10.

reviewText:
Legacy of Kain Soul Reaver is the sequel to Blood Omen, and my god did it ramp things up quite a lot.

The plot is, after the main character of the last game conquered the world. He kills you and throws you into an abyss. After that your corpse is resurrected and you have to traverse a dead world you helped destroy inorder to kill your murderer.

The game is focused on puzzles moreso then combat, due to the fact you actually cannot die. The player instead shifts between the lightless and weightless dimension of the dead to the material realm. This is very important for specific puzzles and sidequests. The game takes place in a semi-open world with no loading screens.

Another big part of Soul Reaver is just how many sidequests there are. Just running through the game will land the character with no health upgrades and no special glyph powers. Should the player return to prior areas you can find new things that you didn't see previously.

However there are some minor flaws.The game ends on a cliffhanger that leads directly into Soul Reaver 2. There is also an entire website devoted to all the content that was cut prior to release.

The other important aspect of this game is it's port. SR1's PC port is flawed in a few ways. Much of the soundtrack doesn't play at specific moments, and this reduces the quality of the game in a lot of unfortunate ways. It remains a bit of buyer beware in that regard.

reviewText:
For more reviews and gameplay videos by Morgoth, check out my  Steam profile, the  Youtube channel, and the Twitch channel[twitch.tv]!!
So this is the very first time I've ever played through any Legacy of Kain game, and after beating down Soul Reaver, I am overwhelmingly impressed.  Soul Reaver is an action/adventure/puzzle solving game in where you (Raziel), are harnessing a deep hatred for your former leader and pseudo-father figure, Kain, that runs so deep that an elder god decides to  utilize you as his weapon of destruction against Kain and his forces, as they have left the entire world in shambles from centuries of war and butchery.  So let's get down to it!

Gameplay:  Definitely one of the high points of this game (and there are many) is just the overall gameplay.  The controls might be a little loose, but the targeting and the executions are spot on.  And fun.  Like, suprisingly fun.  Nothing quite like taking a spear from a wall and impaling a demon/vampire creature straight through the abdomen, while absorbing it's soul afterwards for sustenance.  If this sounds like fun, definitely get this game because you will be doing this a lot.  Don't misunderstand though.  Incredibly, this game actually focuses more on puzzles rather than direct action.  Even boss fights are generally a small puzzle that needs to be solved, rather than directly assaulting the giant, horrific monstrosities (because let's face it, that immediately doesn't sound like a good idea as soon as you see any of the bosses).

Oh, and this game is not exactly easy.  Some of the platforming can be very difficult due to the loose controls, and the world does not exactly hold your hand.  It is very open-ended.  Very few hints are littered throughout the world to guide you on your way, but just enough is given to you if you really pay attention to what is being said.  In an age of games that practically play themselves, this particular type of difficulty in a game is a very welcome feeling.

The only slightly negative part of this game are the overwhelming amount of block puzzles.  Block puzzles.  Block puzzles.  BLOCK PUZZLES.  At any point in time through the game, it's a good bet that a block puzzle is within at least two rooms of where you are currently located.  They are interesting, but the developers really went all out with these puzzles.  None of them are too overwhelmingly difficult, but when they're in every room, it becomes mundane and repetitive.

Graphics:  Fantastic graphics for it's time.  Remember that this game did come out in 1999.  A mere three years after Super Mario 64.  There are a lot of clipping issues obviously for this particular period in time when this game was developed, but overall the game is pretty gorgeous.  Animations are very smooth, enemies are interesting, environments are gloomy and downright spooky, and bosses are horrendously disgusting looking.  Even for today's games, those bosses are the things of nightmares.

Sound:  So the sound in this game is phenomenal, and probably the highlight of the entire game (at least it was for me).  Every movement makes a sound that is very adequate for what it is representing, but the sountrack that kicks in every once and a while is perfect for the theme of the game.  Dark, gothic, and eerie.  Partners perfect with what is happening on the screen at all times.  Especially the opening cutscene music, that also just happens to play near the end during a particularly important part of the game.  Oh, and the voice acting talent is, for lack of a better word, incredible.  Tony Jay is still severely missed.  The script is so well written that several games that are released these days, could learn a lot from sitting down and playing this game.

Lasting Appeal:  So the total game took me about 12 hours to beat, and that's exploring a good amount of the world.  Didn't go for 100%, but pretty close.  Beyond reliving the adventure again, there is not too much reason to revisit this game after beating it.


TL;DR - Great gameplay with a few flaws + decent graphics + fantastic audio + incredible story = 8/10

PC PROBLEMS:  I would strongly recommend against using they keyboard and mouse controls (even though it is possible to just use them), and follow the community guide in the hub that points you to XPadder so that controller use can become enabled.  It is a very short and easy to follow guide that will have you using a controller flawlessly within ten minutes.

Also, I know other Steam users are claiming that the game would crash on them constantly, but I personally never had this problem.  I only ran into a few glitches in which I decided to restart because the audio would fall behind drastically, but if anything that was just an annoyance and I wasn't forced to restart if I didn't choose to.

reviewText:
This game was one I had vague memories of playing a demo of. So, when I found the collection was available on PC for $5, I quickly scooped it up because Gaben.

TLDR: Moar Puzzle, Less Fight. Like? Buy. Not like? PASS

Overview: This game takes place in a land called Nosgoth. You play a death angel who turns into a zombie-vampire hybrid who can't die now. Your job is to get revenge on Kain, for leaving you in this ghoulish state, and then ruining Nosgoth while you were in the underworld. The game truly is an Eidos title in more ways than one.

Pacing:

The game's pacing is nonexistant. It managed to feel the same during all 10 hours I played. Maybe it picks up later on, I don't know tbph. Once could call it postapocalyptic.

Gameplay-Combat:

The combat just seems to lack flow. Many many areas are full of enemies that respawn so constantly that it's almost not worth it to fight them every time, and just run+jump past them. Or use Spirit Realm if you can get away with it. The first boss of the game is a puzzle boss. Bleh. Without spoiling anything, I had to use a walkthrough in the same manner I used a walkthrough with HeXeN.

Gameplay-Puzzles: BLOCK PUZZLES, SON. Also, stuff that isn't obvious. Painful and requires a walkthrough beyond the first twenty minutes or so.

Story: The story is an odd thing, one that doesn't irk me or compel me. Perhaps it's because the first game in the series isn't available for PCs. The game manages to advance the story without drowning you in exposition too much, although there are a few too many cutscenes for my liking.

Controls: Standard clunky PS1-ported-to-PC controls. Can't even use a mouse. A shame, because i'd love to LOOK UP.

So, in conclusion, I can't wholeheartedly reccommend or deny LoK:Soul Reaver, in spite of me being forced to put a NO. It depends. Do you like Tomb Raider and other similar games? Liked HeXeN? Dive right into this gem. Want a more actiony thing to play? AVOID. The puzzles get to the point of feeling forced, imo.

reviewText:
Legacy of Kain Soul Reaver is a forgotten gem that spawned one of the best written and best voice acted franchises I've ever seen. Sadly, the industry is at a constant change and this game couldn't just keep up with it's speed.
Let's start with the good elements, the story.
Soul Reaver tells the tale of Raziel, a vampire damned to an eternity of agony by his creator Kain. Who somehow survived his descent into the lake of the Dead and is now transformed into a ghoul, a shell of his former self. Raziel then swears to get his revenge against the man who once betrayed him and who has now led his land to ruin.

First things first, the writing is just amazing. From the brooding, gothic narrations of our character Raziel, to the shakespearean speeches of our antagonist Kain. Amy Hennig surely did a great job of defining who these characters were and a way to identify this game among the ocean of poorly written cash grabs that plagued the industry at it's time. World building is in every corner of this game, from little tidbits about the lore to just small visual details of the dark and Gothic steampunk fantasy setting of Nosgoth. Which was something you didn't really see that much in 1999.
The voice acting is amazing and it still holds up to this day, from Michael Bell's gothic narrations of Raziel, to Simon Templeman's defiant and perfect representation of the amazing villain that is Kain.
In fact, this game's opening sequence has to be the best opening sequence I have ever seen in a game, it's visuals look great (even today kinda), the voice acting and narration not only manages to set the character motivations and general setting, but it also manages to be great at it.
The problem with the story though, is the ending. Without spoiling that much all I can tell you is that the game ends in your average To be Continued..." cliffhanger

reviewText:
This game is really fantastic. It combines puzzles with a pretty nice fighting system and one hell of a cool story to top it all off. If any of you have played the original release on PS1 you already know this game hasn't been named one of the best games on PS1 without a reason.

However this port is quite unsatisfactionary to say the least. It plays just like on PS1, it looks good and I had no problem with setting up my controler to work with it (be sure to not only change the configuration of the controler in game but also to select it to be the prefered method of playing from the pause menu in order to make it work) but there is one huge problem. It crashes randomly. I have tried multiple different resolution settings but either way it crashes every now and then.

I have managed to get only about 4 crashes throughout the whole game but at the very end of the game, there are a lot of cutscenes and I had to replay all of them at least 5 times to get past them. It would always crash. Finally, I decided to check for integrity of the game cache (which is an option that can be found when you right click the game in your library and then go to properities) and it found 2 corrupted files. Guees what? One of them was my save file and it got deleted. Right before the last boss fight. All in all, I have managed to find a save file at this exact point on the internet and I have finished the game but I am still quite dissapointed that Crystal Dynamics have done nothing about this problem.

To sum it all up - If you like adventure games with good combat system, original story, puzzles and a big world to explore (with a lot of secrets to find, optionally) then this game is definitely for you. Even after over a decade this game still feels right and puts a lot of newer titles to shame. If you don't want to deal with multiple crashes though, you're probably better off buying the original PS1 version and playing it on some sort of emulator.

Oh and if you're wondering about gameplay time, it takes about 16-17 hours to complete if you decide to find most of the glyphs and some of the health upgrades but it should take even up to 30 hours (or more?) if you decide to find every upgrade and all of the glyphs. It might also vary a lot depending on how well you solve puzzles. It sometimes takes long time to figure out what to do. I used a guide only twice but I suppose it was much more rewarding to not use it more.

Don't let that low playtime deceive you; I've spent more time in Soul Reaver on the console than I'd care to mention.

This game has an absolutely riveting, Gothic story narrated by some of the BEST voice actors to ever grace the field (RIP Tony Jay), solid gameplay, decent block puzzles, and more secret content than you can shake a stick at.

Speaking of the secret content... Dear GOD is there a lot of it! It is possible to complete the game, start to finish, and only experience about 40% of the entire game! There are so many glyphs, eldritch energy pickups, and life coil extension pickups that you can get lost in just collecting the miscellanious crap!

Combat can be hit-or-miss (moreso on the PC than the console because of the movement controls), but overall it feels visceral and satisfying; there is something disturbingly cathartic about beating a vampire about the head and neck area before tossing him bodily onto the nearest pointy bit of architecture.

However, I WILL admit that this game has not aged well graphically. At all. The opening movie aside (which shames current-gen consoles TO THIS DAY I might add), everything is hilariously blocky, even by late-90's standards, and it was one of those games where no one had a moving mouth texture.... Origami graphics aside, the game is a source of nostalgic eyecandy from the Dreamcast/PSX-era gamers on here; you can thank Soul Reaver for pioneering continuous-streaming, open-world games like GTAV.

TL;DR
Pros
+engaging, well-delivered story
+Visceral, satisfying combat
+Mind-bendingly horrific boss battles that lend a sense of power to their participants
+Epic traversal and mobility mechanics
+A large, fairly-open world full of rich, well-written lore
+Tony Jay, Michael Bell, Simon Templeman and Anna Gunn all in the same game

Cons
-This game has NOT aged well
-You can tell a lot was cut out of the game before release
-PC controls handle like a technologically-advanced turd
-Low replay value except for story
-Major audio glitch (rare as it is) can wreck enjoyment quickly

I remember wanting this game as a kid, so I jumped at the chance to get it. Legacy of Kain: Soul Reaver is a great game. The agency, while it takes some time to become competent with due to poor but doable controls, feels really good. As you play you become better at playing, almost as if mirroring Razael's revival and strengthening. The game has a steady drip of interesting lore and a plot that leaves you wondering what the next part is. The puzzles often have you stumped until you remember that you can change the world by changing planes, which adds a layer of depth to them. The combat feels pretty decent but simple and can take a bit to become good as different enemies actually have slightly different approaches. The boss fights though are almost all amazing in that they are not blunt fighting but more puzzles. When you die you simply shift to the spectral plane, giving you a chance to come up with a new plan. The platforming, much like the typical combat, is simple. Unlike the combat though, gets more depth as you unlock more abilities.\n\nObviously the game has its flaws: dated graphics, occasional crashes with no catalyst, poor controls, and the such. If this game has caught your eye at all, I'd definitely recommend it.

According to Steam, I played this for twenty-one hours. I could say that isn't really the case. A lot of that time was spent trying to get it to work. The game would work perfectly one day, then would just stop working on another. There are even times where it crashes taking a few steps after the game lets you play. Not to mention the amount of times I had to reinstall this game.

Although I'm totally fine with the game only being 30FPS, I tried SRHook to play it at 60. Doing so will make the game skip all the cinematics. I asked on the Game's Discussion page if there was a way to still get the cinematics to play while using SRhook, and was told that there isn't anything that can be done. So, I just decided to remove SRHook when I got to parts that had cinematic cutscenes.

I used a Dualshock 4 and Inputmapper to map the controller buttons to be keyboard inputs since just using an xinput controller won't make it work properly.

It's really a shame that this game suffers from these problems as it's still pretty solid during the times when it actually worked. It felt like it did when I first played it on the Playstation, I never finished it then, which is why I got it here on Steam. Besides the problems stated above, I didn't encounter any game breaking bugs or glitches. Just make sure that when using SRHook, cap the framerate at 60 as it'll mess the game up a bit when played higher than that, specifically with some puzzles that need the constrict ability. But that's not the game's fault. The gameplay still holds up, each boss isn't just a straight up fight, and are themselves puzzles (except for two). The story is a big part of the whole Legacy of Kain saga, and is still in my opinion one of the best in gaming to this day.

If you can put up with the crashing, and are lucky enough to not have the game stop working at all, it'll be a good experience. If you have very little patience with these things, you may want to pass on this version and play it on the PS3 or if you still have your PS1.

Not a bad port. Always loved this game, so I'm a bit biased. Take it from me, this series has one of the best stories in gaming period. Try it out if you like it I defy you not to play all of the others just to unravel the tale. Destiny, time travel, interdimensional conspiracies, vampires, and false gods this game is the best place to enter into the series. Between the voice acting and the writing this game is good enough, but Soul Reaver boasts the most enjoyable gameplay in the whole series.

The enemies and the environments work togather to create an interative playground for you to test out different and creative ways to clear out rooms. There are several ways to stun enemies from beating the hell out of them, to psychokenetic force balls to throwing rando crap at their faces. And once you've gotten them stunned they're your toys. You can grab them and throw them at hazars like spikes or flames, off cliffs or into the brimy deep. Impale them from afar or up close. It's just too much fun to experiment with.

The big plus that always had me entranced with this game is there is no death and no fail state. Your experience flows and remains fun regardless of how good or bad you are doing. While in the physical world if your health is brought down to zero, the world is transformed into the spectral realm. This changes the shape of the world and the enemies that spawn. Devour enough souls and you can return to the physical world die in the specral realm and you are transported back to the first room in the game. This would be frustrating if it werent for the fact that along your journey you discover way gates, and there is a gate right after the first room. So you rarely actually lose progress and through all of this there is nary a load screen.

All and all I've played the whole series and love each part for different reasons but this the the best in terms of the total package. If you haven't tried it yet start here.

I had ALL KINDS of strupid issues trying to get this to run on windows 10, and even more issues trying to get it to function with an Xone controller.......... but I did get everything working, and I am glad. The environments and story in this game draw me in pretty deeply. No matter what gen gamer you are, this game is a timeless classic.

Hints for Windows 10 users:

Make sure you select a resolution that is x32 instead of x 16. The x32 resolutions are at the top of the list rather than the bottom where one would normally find them.

Don't even mess with the graphics settings in game, use your Graphics card to set up effects and aa values. The only thing you need the launcher or in game settings for is to set the resolution.

No matter what kind of hardware you have, chjoose the rendering option that mentions direct x.

If you wanna use a 360 or Xone controller you will have to set the control option to KEYBOARD and then press the buttons on the controller in keyboard settings. Analog controls simply do not work with this game unless you are using Pinnacle Game Profiler or something else that is able to read analog input as mopuse coordinates.

Expect to spend some time getting the game to work on W10............
